title-group.article-title: Aluminum phosphide-induced genetic and oxidative damages in rats: attenuation by Laurus nobilis leaf extract

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Molecular Biology and Genetics, Faculty of Sciences, Erzurum Technical University, Turkey
2Department of Biology, Faculty of Sciences, Atatürk University, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: Başak Toğar, Department of Biology, Faculty of Sciences, Atatürk University, 25240 Erzurum, Turkey. Email: basaktogar@gmail.com

abstract.p: Aluminum phosphide (AlP) is a colorless, flammable, liquefied pesticide that is commonly used to control insects, nematodes, weeds, and pathogens in crops, forests, ornamental nurseries, and wood products. Early investigations of AlP-poisoned mammalian cells led to the proposed involvement of oxidative damage in its toxicity mechanism. Therefore, this study was aimed to evaluate the effect of Laurus nobilis (L) leaf extract (LNE) against AlP-induced genetic and oxidative damages in rats. Selected animals were assigned to four groups (n = 6), namely, group A: control (only distilled water is injected); group B: AlP (4 mg kg−1 injected intraperitoneally (i.p.)); group C: LNE (200 mg kg−1 injected i.p.), and group D: AlP plus LNE, respectively. The experimental period lasted for 14 successive days. Chromosomal aberrations (CAs) and micronucleus (MN) assay were used for monitoring genotoxic damage. In addition, biochemical parameters such as total antioxidant capacity (TAC) and total oxidative status (TOS) were examined in serum samples to determine oxidative damage. Our results indicated that AlP caused increase in CA and MN assay rates and alterations in TAC and TOS levels when compared with control group. On the contrary, LNE did not change the rates of both the analyzed cytogenetic end points and led to increase in TAC level. Moreover, we observed that LNE suppressed the genetic damage by AlP to bone marrow cells in vivo. Interestingly AlP-induced oxidative stress was also strongly reduced by LNE. The results of the present study indicated that the protective effect of LNE might be ascribable to its antioxidant and free radical scavenging properties.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Laurus nobilis L. is an evergreen tree widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Europe. It has been used for its astringent, healing, and diuretic properties (Speroni et al., 2011). This plant is used in folk medicine for stomachic and carminative remedies as well as for the treatment of gastric diseases in many parts of the world (De Marino et al., 2004; Otsuka et al., 2008; Nayak et al., 2006). Moreover, recent experimental results indicated that L. nobilis (L) leaf extract (LNE) had exhibited antioxidant (Kaurinovic et al., 2010), antibacterial (Otsuka et al., 2008), and insecticidal properties (Zaitoun, 2007).

On the other hand, phosphine (PH3) is an important insecticide and rodenticide generated from aluminum phosphide (AlP) or zinc phosphide (Hsu et al., 1998, 2002). PH3 is also used widely to protect grain in stores and during its transportation (Proudfoot, 2009). PH3 is a highly toxic compound that can be produced from the reaction of metal phosphides with water (Kligerman et al., 1994). Although it has widespread use in agricultural and other applications, AlP was considered toxic in various organs like liver, heart, and kidney of mammals (Okolie et al., 2004). AlP also induced oxidative stress in insects, mammalian cells, animals, and humans (Dua and Gill 2001; Hsu et al., 2002). Moreover, AlP was a suspected carcinogen and a known clastogen, which had been shown to produce chromosome damage in agricultural workers (Tucker et al., 2003).

Since AlP was developed, its toxic effects mainly via oxidative stress (Hsu et al., 2000), antioxidants, or antioxidant-like compounds can be used as most effective protectors against its harmful effects on humans and animals. Limited efforts were performed to explore protective agents to minimize AlP toxicity. In fact, some antioxidant-natured compounds including ethanolamine lipids (Kuczynski and Reo 2006), melatonin, glutathione (Hsu et al., 2000, 2002), and sweet almond (Saidi and Shojaie, 2011) were examined for chemoprevention. For this reason, it is worth carrying out an experimental evaluation of the protective role of LNEs against AlP-induced oxidative and genotoxic damages in Sprague-Dawley rat model. In fact, chromosomal aberration (CA) and micronucleus (MN) tests are widely applied in genotoxicity testing and biomonitoring. Both the assays were developed as simpler and reliable short-term screening tests (Turkez and Geyikoglu, 2011; Turkez et al., 2011). In addition to important oxidative parameters, total antioxidant capacity (TAC) and total oxidative status (TOS) levels were used to monitor the antioxidant or pro-oxidant activities in vivo (Türkez and Toğar, 2010, Turkez et al., 2010).

sec.title: Plant materials and extracts
sec.p: Leaf samples for various extractions and processing experiments were collected from the Mersin-Silifke region in Turkey in May 2010. Leaf samples were handpicked randomly from the trees. They were dried in the shade and crushed. After crushing, 100 g of powdered leaves was extracted. The extract was manufactured from the dried leaves of L. nobilis by applying ethyl acetate extraction procedure.

sec.title: Animals and chemicals
sec.p: Experiment was carried out on male Sprague–Dawley rats, 8 weeks old, weighing 180–200 g. The animals were kept on a 12-h light–dark cycle and allowed free access to food and water. All experiments were performed in accordance with the Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals (National Research Council, 1996). AlP (Cas No 20859-73-8) was also obtained from the company Detia Degesch® (Laudenbach, Germany). All other chemicals were purchased from Sigma® (St. Louis, MO, USA).

sec.title: Experimental design
sec.p: The animals were randomly divided into four equal groups (n = 6): group A: rats were given an equivalent of distilled water, group B: rats received LNE (200 mg/kg intraperitoneally (i.p.)), group C: rats received AlP (4 mg/kg i.p.), and group D: rats received LNE plus AlP for 14 days i.p. The doses were selected according to the literature data (Hsu et al., 2002; Nayak et al., 2006). After the treatment, the animals were anesthetized with ether.

sec.title: Biochemical and cytogenetic studies
sec.p: Blood samples were collected into serum separator tubes (Microtainer; Becton Dickinson, Franklin Lakes, New Jersey, USA), allowed to stand for 75–90 min, centrifuged at 860g for 20 min, and serum samples were obtained. The automated TAC and TOS assays were carried out by commercially available kits (Assay Diagnostics, Turkey) on serum samples (Erel, 2004 , 2005). Bone marrow cell preparations for the analysis of CAs (gaps and breaks) were produced by the colchicine–hypotonic citrate technique. Potassium chloride (0.075 M) was used in this technique. Colchicine (0.1%, 1 ml/100 g body weight) was injected i.p. 90 min before killing the animals. Animals were killed and then bone marrow cells were flushed from the femora with 0.075 M potassium chloride. Slides were prepared by an air-drying procedure and stained with 5% Giemsa stain. For MN analysis, bone marrow was isolated from the other femur bone with the help of syringes and homogenized with fetal bovine serum. The slides were coded, fixed with methanol, and stained with Giemsa solution. From each animal, 2000 polychromatic erythrocytes were scored for MN presence. Slides were scored at a magnification of 1000× using a light microscope by one observer (B.T.).

sec.title: Statistics
sec.p: The statistical analysis of experimental values in the TAC-TOS and CA and MN analyses was performed by one-way analysis of variance and Fisher’s least significant difference test using the SPSS 13.0 software. The level of 0.05 was regarded as indicative of statistical significance for all the tests.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The statistically significant elevations of CA and MN were observed after exposure to AlP for 14 days. On the other hand, 200 mg kg−1 LNE did not induce significant (p < 0.05) increase in the observed CA and MN rates as compared to the control group. Moreover, LNE reduced the number of AlP-induced CA and MN formations, but it did not completely inhibit the AlP-caused genetic damages (Table 1). Table 1 also shows the effect of LNE and AlP on oxidant status in serum samples, which was determined by TAC and TOS analysis. As shown in the table, the TAC value decreased with the addition of AlP, while TOS value increased. In contrast, LNE did not alter the TOS level but increased the TAC level. Besides, the LNE had inhibitory effects on oxidative damage in serum samples by AlP.

caption.p: The oxidative (levels of TAC and TOS) and genotoxic (rates of MN and CA) assessments in rats exposed simultaneously to AlP and LNE for 14 days.a

fn.p: AlP: aluminum phosphide; LNE: L. nobilis leaf extract; TAC: total antioxidant capacity; TOS: total oxidative status; MNPCE: micronucleated polychromatic erythrocytes, CA: chromosomal aberration; MN: micronucleus; bw: body weight.
aValues are means ± SD of six experiments. Means shown by different letter are significantly different from each other at a level of 5%.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The present findings clearly revealed that the AlP induced genotoxic damage in the rat bone marrow cells. So the observed MN and CA rates were found to be statistically higher than that in the control group. In accordance with our finding, Barbosa et al. (1994) found a statistically significant increase in MN frequency in the bone marrow and spleen lymphocytes in mice. In an in vitro study on Hepa 1c1c7 cells, it was determined that the exposure to AlP caused an elevation of 8-hydroxyguanine level, which is a major premutagenic lesion generated from reactive oxygen species (ROS) (Hsu et al., 1998). On the contrary, the results for MN showed no significant differences between PH3 fumigators and control individuals (Barbosa and Bonin, 1994). But, it was also reported that fumigant applicators exposed to PH3 had significantly increased stable chromosome rearrangements, primarily translocations in G-banded lymphocytes (Garry et al., 1989). Our findings also revealed that AlP leads to oxidative damage on blood cells of rats. In this study, AlP caused an increase in TOS level and decrease in TAC level as compared to the control group. In parallel with this finding, it was suggested previously that the PH3-induced mutagenic and cytotoxic effects were due to increased ROS levels, probably hydroxyl radicals, initiating oxidative damage (Hsu et al., 1998, 2002). In addition, Proudfoot (2009) suggested that PH3 caused hydroxyl radical-associated damage such as lipid peroxidation by inhibiting catalase and peroxidase enzymes.

The present investigation also determined that LNE is protected against oxidative and genetic damages by AlP. O'Brien et al. (2006) provided evidence that nonnutrient dietary constituents could act as significant bioactive compounds and several plant extracts. As a matter of fact, a very high level of antioxidant activity of L. nobilis diet was observed in bovine brain (Conforti et al., 2006). Similarly, Speroni et al. (2011) found that oral administration of LNE were in good agreement with their antioxidant capacity, confirming the relationship between pharmacological efficacy and antiradical activity. Recent reports also exhibited the neuroprotective, cardioprotective, and antidiabetic properties of LNE (Cho et al., 2010; Dall’Acqua et al., 2009; Khan and Zaman, 2009). Ham et al. (2010) determined the phytochemical composition of L. nobilis leaves and found 10 flavonoid O-glycosides, one flavonoid C-glycoside, catechin, and cinnamtannin B1. All of these compounds were reported to have more or less antioxidant potentials (Ho et al., 1999; Rababah et al., 2011; Souza et al., 2007).

As a conclusion, we suggest that improper disposal of AlP into the aquatic or terrestrial ecosystems can cause considerable levels of oxidative DNA damage among living organisms. However, LNE can hinder such toxic impacts. The plant, thereby, can serve as a prospective source of natural metabolites, which could prove to be precursors for designing effective preventive or protective agents against AlP toxicity.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
